review_title: If you really need a Job, they have it.
pros:
- Most staff are very friendly and pleasant. 
- Will pay wages according to years of experience
- Need a job? They have a lot openings!
cons:
- Management from top to bottom are very disorganized 
- Most units have a lot of different drama that really has no place in the work place. You can feel the toxic culture on each of the different units and management contributes to a lot of it. 
- It's very apparent that most of the unit managers and their managers lack leadership skills and know how to competently manage and lead their staff. They mostly talk a lot of talk but almost always cannot show that they truly know what they are talking about. It is mostly do as I say or else. 
- Difficult to find answers regarding employment issues
- DMC's mission and values are not exercised and is definitely not promoted for staff or patient care
- It is easy to see how miserable staff are and how they don't really care about the patient experience. They all just go through the motions of their tasks and thats all you will get. Nothing more,
- Need help with Human Resources? Good luck, there are 2-3 people on site and they cant help you with much. They will just refer you to a Tenet Health number or email. With that it will take you many tries, redirections and automated services that will pretty much get you no where. When you do finally get a hold of someone from HR, they have no idea what you are talking about and are unfamiliar with what your issue is about. could take days and many hours to get your answer.
- Benefits aren't the best

pros: Team response to care giving
cons: Need more time off for family csre

pros: the healthcare benefits are top notch, it covers a family for just a very small amount a month, in this economy you cant beat it, the cto is awesome, you start out at 7 per pay period hours that goes into a bank for your personal use, great!
cons: it seems that if you have a problem with a co worker you really have no where to go, you can report it to your supervisor and nothing ever gets done, then you go to hr and nothing happens again and before you know it the horrible person who has been harrassing you knows that they can get away with anything, it gives them power, they can make you miserable evey day and there isnt any recourse, people are afriad to tell now, no sense in telling, nothing will happen

pros: It's close to my house and I like the people that I work with  and I love what I do it's time for me to move up in the company
cons: I've been working for the Detroit Medical Center for six and a half years I have replied no more list of times for Thursday position I have had several interviews but have not received a call back and I don't understand that and that's what I don't like about the Detroit Medical Center is supposed to be a learning hospital but they give you such a hard time trying to advance within the company so that's why I'm looking for another employee that has more flexibility with the staff is already there as far as moving around to move up the ladder

pros: Not much anymore. Some of staff in department are team players, but everyone is so done with all the lies from management. Everyone is burnt out from neglect.
cons: We have no permanent manager for many reasons, but mainly because the last manager was burnt out from all the ridiculous demands put on managers. In order to get one RN hired all RN's got a raise while others, many of whom have more education and professionalism were left severely underpaid. Management continues to give excuses. Higher paid staff is salary and has greater privileges, but are not held to a hire standard. Their error are either ignored, or never known. And if you do bring issues to management you are the one that gets chastised. This is in direct opposition to what the company claims will be done with complaints. So much more I can say, but anyone working in healthcare these days knows exactly where I'm coming from.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Detroit, MI
pros: They offer great shift hours
cons: They offer horrible yearly raises

pros: Easy work and easy to get a job, first time employees are wanted : does pay well do to the fact they can't keep or recruit experienced employees
cons:
401k Match : Discretionary 
Health care : must use DMC facilities
1% raises (equals $0.21-$0.25 a year : Inflation is 3-4% so you get poorer in real world value every year you work there 
Will make you work with 4-5 therapist if call offs
No overtime

review_title: Its not what you know, but WHO you know
pros: Diverse work environment, the opportunity to interact with different types of people.  Hospital security is the best at what they do, they encourage a safe work environment.
cons: Employee engagement is awful, employees are not recognized for their hard work unless they are a part of " the in crowd", or the friends and family program.  Too much nepotism, and it causes a very unfair working environment.  Management is selected by if they are liked or not by the upper management.  HR is biased as well. Everchanging without consistency.  Overall just not a place to work if you are used to being in a hardworking fair environment.

pros: Good pay, I'm lucky to have a good boss, ok benefits if you stay within DMC. I started at 14.28 and my probationary period was a FULL year. Then I was paid 17.20 per union contract. Good money except for the fact that you cant get a raise, or a promotion based on merit. Many people have been here for over 20 years so they have seniority. I worry about being bumped and losing my job.
cons: Union membership. This is a Right to Work state which means you don't have to pay union dues if you don't want to but they still have to represent you and unfortunately you are under their bargaining agreement. Know your rights before you start. Also, depending on which hospital you work at, you will see A LOT of "frequent flyers" who are allowed to come in and they give them IV "medications."

pros: The patients you care for and the coworkers.
cons: Before the company went from non profit status, i had found my dream job. I loved everything about working there. Since our status change to for profit. You dont feel stabe in your position, you are not appreciated no matter how hard you work. There is favoritism between managment and staff. Your outta luck if you are not one of the favorites, privledged assignment and scheduling. The health system is all about profits now not about caring for the patients. We have the cheapest supplies ever and are always understaffed or have too many patients to care for adequately. Everyday after you work a 12 hour shift you feel like a truck has hit you. Mandatory education which is fine but you have to do it on your own time at home. Moral is in the gutter and no one seems to care about the nurses. I do NOT reccomend this as a place to work.

pros: The insurance is good to have and the company offers tuition reimbursement.
cons: The department is completely overworked.  Never recognize when you've gone above and beyond the call of duty, management is no help when in  need of help and is very vindictive if you go over their head go get the help you need. Little to no room for growth or advance opportunities within the department or company. They only hire men instead of women

review_title: Would NOT work for Tenet again
pros: You learn a lot, but that's because you're overworked. If you move between Tenet facilities you keep your seniority.
cons: Since becoming a Tenet hospital there have been significant, and rather unsavory, changes. Particularly in that they have removed the care out of patient care. The focus is too much on financial bottom line, meaning they've cut staff repeatedly, often at the cost of the patient. Employee benefits have gone down the drain, despite Tenet's promise that nothing would change with our insurance. Above all, Tenet no longer cares about the "why" of what we do, to help patients and our community. They only care about pleasing investors.

review_title: I started as a volunteer and worked my way up to coordinator.
pros: There are many doors that can be opened at the DMC if you have the right individuals behind you to encourage and elevate your career. The exposure is wonderful. The reason I went to DMC was to help my daughter with her education of being a pathologist, my plan was to keep a foot in the door for her to eventually get in to. I learned a lot.
cons: Restructuring of departments happened a lot. I never seen where the results accomplishment what they were designed to do. Employees get anxious when they are turned topsy- turvy with no real goal or benchmarks set.

review_title: The people there are great. The Management is horrible.
pros: The people and diversity is amazing. You meet people there from all over the world and get to work on cutting edge discovers and state of the art procedures.
cons: Management is horrible. One of my coworkers was moved to a desk job and 2 of my coworkers were fired. I am now the only person that is left that actually works. Everyone else in my group is a supervisor. I now have 4 bosses and still can not get any of them to actually make a decision.

pros: I worked 27 years as an RN, but decided to retire early.  In my career, I have met some beautiful people...staff and patients.  I never would have had the blessing of meeting these people and caring for their needs if I was not an RN.  As a patient, I received excellent care from the physicians and the staff.  There are many dedicated, hardworking staff at the DMC.
cons: Since TENET took over, I see a decline in the quality of care because of the staffing cuts.  There is a disrespect in the way staff are treated by TENET.  I have seen management who have dedicated many years of their lives to the DMC be walked out by security because they were no longer needed.  There is a lack of honour and respect for those people who gave years of sweat and blood to make the DMC what it is today.  It hurts me to see this.  Another problem is the cuts in staffing.  I realize that there are financial concerns and I don't know what their budget is.  Health care is costly to pay staff and for the supplies needed to run a hospital.  Cutting costs is a reality, but at the same time, patients deserve excellent care.  It is difficult to make hourly rounds when I have 6 couplets on postpartum.  This is 12 patients to care for and chart on.  I can't do it anymore.  I feel like I am running in circles just to barely get the job done.  To me it is not just a job.  It is a vocation which involves interaction and care of patients....not running from room to room spending very minimal time with each person.  If there is an emergency with a patient then it is awful because no other patients can receive excellent care if you are tied up.  The cuts in clerks make it impossible to be with the patients, chart, and answer phones and call lights.  The desk is chaotic.  Also, when an employee is off on medical leave, we have limited income, yet we receive this bill to pay for the medical care and if it is not paid we are cut off of medical care when we need a physician most.  I see people undergoing chemotherapy and all sorts of health problems coming back to work early, while they are still not well, so they don't lose their medical care.  It is awful that staff who dedicate their life to the hospital are treated this way.  I don't want to be an RN anymore because I find it too stressful the way health care is changing to cut costs at the expense of the patients and the staff.  I don't like the way my fellow coworker's in management were treated after years of service.  They are not just numbers, they are people who dedicated their lives to make the hospital what it is today.  I am leaving and retiring early  to enjoy the rest of my life.  I had a great career and I wish everyone the best in their career.  It is all about just enjoying the people we interact with, despite the changes and cuts.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Detroit, MI
pros:
Large hospital system to network/transfer
Medical/vision/dental benefits were great 
CTO was great for me because I was grandfathered in to DMC's previous plan before Vanguard and then Tenet took over
cons:
Departmental heads did not listen to lower level staff's opinions/suggestions for improvement 
Due to Tenet taking over, some of the "good" that made DMC the family environment it was...was taken away.

pros: Used to be a good place to work when patient care was it's top priority.
cons: Ever since Tenet took over this hospital system has taken a serious nose dive. So many staff nurses have left that we are often short and have to take higher patient ratios. High up executives round units each morning with their useless checklists to "improve" the surroundings of the unit, when it's just in fact mindless and useless decisions that they're making and constantly making our jobs harder and worse. This system constantly moves around hospital presidents and executives from one hospital to the next. This hospital system is in need of a serious "clean up" of these executives making these "valuable" decisions. Tenet is constantly cutting, cutting, cutting to make a profit in exchange for poor and unsafe patient care. Terrible company.

pros: Steady Job, Good Benefits, Great location in the city of Detroit where many new gentrified locations are popping up. The hospital is always updating and adding new things such as the new eatery they have created.
cons: No consistency, no room for growth. Management is ok but constantly changing every 2-3 years. The hospital seems to constantly be coming under hot water for always changing and selling company ownership. Many people become afraid of losing their jobs.

review_title: Selling hospital system to Vanguard, destroyed it for employees
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Commerce Township, MI
pros: Vanguard did build a new hospital in Detroit which was good for the community however....the hospitals outside of Detroit were treated like step children.
cons: I was let go, along with many experienced staff.  The geriatric clinic where I was employed was shuttered, deserting hundreds of elderly patients, telling them to drive from north-western Oakland County to downtown Detroit for their care at the Rosa Parks Geriatric Clinic.  Rosa Parks Geriatric Clinic is an award winning center, however; anyone who works with seniors, knows they will not drive over 30 miles to see a doctor in a city with a reputation that isn't the greatest.  Many experienced staff from nurses to social workers to management were let go and the entire staff became vigilant as their teams shrunk and they were expected to do more for the same pay.  Moral remains poor among staff from talking to people who remain employed at DMC.

job_title: Director Revenue Cycle in Detroit, MI
pros:
Strong revenue cycle team and mid-level management team with average tenure of over 14 years. Successfully redefined expectations for two major divisions that had preconceived determination of failure based upon poor outcomes from predecessor.  

Made a strong contribution and provided leadership as member of Technology Committee resulting in adoption of my recommendations of PM/EMR vendor ultimately selected.  Additionally, was asked by leadership to provide guidance, development of implementation strategies for working group.

Through redevelopment of organizational processes, structure, processes that produced drastic reduction in percentage of A/R outstanding, achieved buy-in and support from Coding Department resulting in improving working relationship that produced improved delivery days for charges.

Through my oversight role of the third party billing company contracted with the group, improved efficiencies, standardization of revenue generation, enhancement of solutions and delivery of stronger data for strategic analysis.  Through this oversight, influenced billing company to adhere to reach and meet MGMA top 10% industry standards for productivity, error rate percentage, Days in A/.R.
cons: Diverse set and scope of challenges, ranging from maneuvering through multiple organizational structural entrenchments to obtaining the level of support from counterparts within the hospital system via atypical silo mentality

review_title: Good Job before Vanguard Tenet Acqusition
pros: Great Benefits and growth within the organization is/was relatively easy. Great Tuition reimbursement and Employee perks.
cons: Recent layoff and pay freezes have decreased employee moral.  Much older work environment which often times makes work dull and mundane.

review_title: A lot of improvements need to be made
pros: They are located in the heart of Midtown Detroit so you are close to a lot of events and activities. Positions are pretty stable, depending on the department. Pay is decent as well as employee perks
cons: Management needs better, quality training. The building I worked in was very very old and outdated. Benefits can be sky high and there is no room for growth whatsoever. Nurses in certain facilities can be very rude and nasty.

pros: There are some Great people working here it’s too bad management is unaware who they are.  Great health insurance. Flexible work schedule.
cons:
No communication from management on any level, unless your part of the click. It’s true that, it’s NOT what you know, it’s who you know. 
Some management spending too much time trying to make themselves look good, they are unable or unwilling to answer the simplest question as it pertains to those they are managing.

pros: Desperate and you really need a job would be the only reason to work at the DMC there are really no pros here they don't even say a simple thank you for staying over they will work you like a dog and one wrong move your in the office getting a write up
cons: Mangement is not fair at all they do not understand that their employees has a life outside of the DMC not to mention the DMC care is expensive but they they switching to Aetna no employee perks at all Mangemant of the Admitting and ER department is horrible they are bully's at the children's hospital

pros: Service to the patients is very good
cons: Within the Health Information Management department, no accountability held on supervision and management when it comes to treating hourly employees ethically nor fairly. Consistent lies from management staff towards their employees and manipulation of policy and procedures despite multiple complaints against management staff. Human resources also share private employee information with lower level management to use against their own hourly employees for disciplinary action or ability to move up in the company.

review_title: My experience in the last 8 years, at the DMC has been educational, compassionate, and friendly.
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Detroit, MI
pros: The management team at the DMC, was informative, accurate, and persistant.
cons: Employees that were not team players, misinformed, lazy, non compliant, and shows no compassion to the sick, elderly, or grieving visitors.

pros: Great Co-workers, many new experiences. Great learning environment. Excellent care by nursing staff. Very respectful place to indigent and wealthy alike. Lots of diversity.
cons: Terrible administration/managers. Childish backstabbing behaviors. Hospital very poor. Low supplies lousy pt accommodations. Staff for some job descriptions very lazy. Short staffed especially during off shifts, could get dangerous.

pros: The learning experience from working with a team will to show customer appreciation daily. The unit 6 Brush was the best due to the level of patient compassion. The doctors always will to sharing his or her wisdom on the floor.
cons: The workforce gossip that management will feed into daily.

pros: I liked gaining knowledge in different facets of the company and learning about new topics or how to do new things.  I really  enjoyed helping others, whether it’s co workers,  or patients.
cons: It's hard to help everyone at the same time.  You would like to please everyone but sometimes its hard when dealing with different characteristics.

pros: Training here allows you to take care of very sick patients with a good amount of autonomy. Overall the training is good.
cons: Staff here are not very conscientious of resident work-life balance. They are often not willing or not able to effectively teach residents.

pros: So happy I’ll be moving on from this poor excuse for a healthcare system. The positive reviews you see are not true at all. Everyone is overworked and miserable.
cons: Lack of administrative support or care. Administration passes the buck on important tasks that are vital for department operations, and those they pass the buck to do not get compensated. When you state the truth about this it’s ignored-because they do not care. Those at the top are only concerned about themselves. It’s sad and pathetic.

pros: Salary is better than most other hospitals in the metro area.  Tuition reimbursement is a great perk.
cons: Poor leaders in place, creates a very poor employee morale.  In cases where HR is involved, they are not helpful either.  Too much nepotism, causing good employees to get overlooked for promotions.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Detroit, MI
pros: The pay is good. It can be a great learning environment if you choose to pursue it.
cons: The scheduling can be a problem for people NOT going to school for a higher degree.

review_title: No training for staf regarding supplies
pros: We have one of the best supply management systems in the country for users.
cons: The users do not get the training needed to use the system properly.

review_title: Loved the work and the people. Just not the company.
pros: Fast paced. Got to learn a lot of medical specialties. Enjoyed the people.
cons: At one point the medical center owed me $10,000 in back wages, some from a year back. I very rarely had a paycheck that was correct.

job_title: Patient Safety Officer in Detroit, MI
pros: great people, great patients, it is very fulfilling to work for such a deserving community
cons: everything is about money. as a for-profit hospital, money is always the bottom line. at the end of the day, when budget isnt met, the first thing to go are people. the company has no loyalty to the people who keep it above water every day

pros: Very professional and friendly, family oriented, easy parking near the entrance, secured by DMC Police security 24hrs. around the clock. Main entrance oors never locked. Flex hours available.
cons: doors to ER/Urgent care not secured and family members when excited can rush in easily, push, shove  and hurt the nursing personnel

pros:
Opportunities to effect organizational improvements exist throughout the company. 
Corporate aquisition may provide the necessary infusion of money to target improvements and enhance organizational capacity.
cons:
Long term leaders are barriers to change.
Financial capital necessary to make improvements are limited.
Employees are resistant to change and pessimistic.

pros: Receiving was the best place to learn any and all medical.  It was one of the best experiences of my life.
